reference.title: Accessibility: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS)
reference.shortdesc: This describes techniques and implementation tips to meet IBM Web Accessibility for Cascading Style Sheets (CSS).

p.xref: IBM Corporate Accessibility Center - CSS checkpoint

section.p: According to accessibility guidelines, when using a cascading style sheet (CSS), we should organize documents so they may be read without style sheets. For example, when an HTML document is rendered without associated style sheets, it must still be possible to read the document.

section.title: Generating content with CSS
section.p: Text generated by style sheets is not part of the document source and will not be available to assistive technologies that access content through the Document Object Model Level 1 (DOM1). To ensure that documents can be read without style sheets, provide text equivalents for any important image or text generated by style sheets (for example, through the background-image, list-style, or content properties). Images generated by style sheets that are purely decorative do not require text equivalents.

section.title: Tabular positioning with CSS
section.p: CSS positioning may be used to create tabular effects. This may cause the document to be read out of order by a screen reader. So, even though the screen reader can read it, the user will not be able to understand it. Consider using a TABLE element to create the same effect.

section.title: Conveying the structure of a document with CSS
section.p: CSS can be used for any text elements to make them appear as headings, titles, lists, etc. If you use CSS to achieve the visual effect you want but don't identify the elements correctly in the document markup, screen reader users will not be able to understand the overall organization of the document. It will just appear to them as one big stream of text. For example, if you use CSS only to differentiate the headings, the screen reader user will not be able to jump from heading to heading to get an outline of the document. Make sure that you also identify headings with the proper hx element.

section.title: Style sheet standards and browsers
section.p:
IBM Home Page Reader 3.0 and most screen readers, such as JAWS, support CSS and most HTML presentation elements in the graphics view. Online resources, such as the
Webreview.com Master Compatibility Chart, outline which CSS features are supported in which browsers. For background and additional information on how accessibility is affected by style sheets, see the W3C's CSS Techniques for Web Content Accessibility Guidelines. These guidelines describe in detail how style sheets might be used to create accessible pages.

ul.li: Provide a text equivalent for any important image or text generated by style sheets (e.g., via the 'background-image', 'list-style', or 'content' properties).

Ensure that important content appears in the document object. Text generated by style sheets is not part of the document source and will not be available to assistive technologies that access content through the Document Object Model Level 1 (DOM1).
Generated content can serve as markers to help users navigate a document and stay oriented when they can't access visual clues such as proportional scrollbars, frames with tables of contents, etc.
Test the home page with the IBM Home Page Reader.
